rule_text: Citations to cases include the case name, reporter information, and date. Cases must be cited in a standardized format that includes all essential elements for identification and retrieval.
formatting_requirements: Case names must be italicized in court documents or underlined/italicized in academic writing
Reporter volume abbreviations must follow Table T1
Court and jurisdiction abbreviations must follow applicable tables
Year must be in parentheses
Pinpoint pages must be included when referencing specific passages

sub_rules.rule_text: A full case citation includes the case name (italicized in court documents or underlined/italicized in academic writing), the published reporter volume, reporter abbreviation, first page of the case, pinpoint page if needed, the court abbreviation (if not obvious from reporter), and the year in parentheses.
formatting_requirements: Case name must be italicized
Reporter volume must precede reporter abbreviation
First page number required
Pinpoint page preceded by comma
Court abbreviation in parentheses with year
Year in parentheses is mandatory

examples.description: U.S. Supreme Court case with pinpoint citation

sub_rules.rule_text: Case names must be formatted according to specific rules for abbreviation and omission of parties and words.
formatting_requirements: Omit first names, middle names, and initials (use only last names)
Omit 'The' as the first word of a party name
Use acronyms for widely known entities (NLRB)
Abbreviate entity designations according to Table T6
Omit all parties except first on each side of the 'v.'
Omit alternative names (AKA, d/b/a)

error_regex_patterns.description: Contains middle initials in case name
Multiple defendants listed (should be omitted after first)

examples.description: Proper case name with last names only

examples.text: John P. Smith v. Mary Jones
examples.description: Incorrect - includes first name and middle initial

sub_rules.rule_text: In case names, omit first names, middle names, and initials of individuals (use just last names). Omit 'The' as the first word of a party name. Use acronyms for entities if widely known ('NLRB'), otherwise abbreviate & according to table T6. Always abbreviate certain words (e.g., 'Co.', 'Inc.' per T6) and any word listed in table T6 when it is part of a party name (except when it is the first word of a party name).
formatting_requirements: Use only last names for individuals
Omit 'The' at beginning
Use standard acronyms for known entities
Abbreviate entity words per Table T6
Abbreviate geographic units per Table T6

error_regex_patterns.description: Contains first and middle names or initials

examples.description: Correct format with last names only
Correct use of acronym and abbreviation

sub_rules.rule_title: Additional Rules for Case Names in Citations
sub_rules.rule_text: Omit all parties other than the first listed on each side of the 'v.' (unless required for clarity, such as ex rel. parties). Also omit alternative names for the first party (like 'AKA' or 'd/b/a' entries). Use 'In re' or 'Ex parte' for certain procedural cases as appropriate. Abbreviate any state, country, or other geographical unit according to T10 when it is part of a case name (except if it's a named party like 'State of...').
formatting_requirements: Omit all but first party on each side of v.
Include ex rel. parties for clarity when needed
Omit AKA and d/b/a designations
Use 'In re' for certain procedural cases
Abbreviate geographic units per Table T10
Preserve named parties like 'State of'

examples.text: Smith ex rel. Johnson v. Jones
examples.description: ex rel. party included for clarity
Multiple parties should be omitted, only first retained

sub_rules.rule_text: For decisions published in reporters, cite to those reporters according to their citation format (e.g., U.S., F.2d, N.E.2d). If a case is unreported, provide an equivalent citation such as a docket number and database identifier, or a court website, or a slip opinion information. For cases in regional reporters, include the region abbreviation. If citing multiple reporters (parallel citations), Bluebook strongly prefers citing only the official or most authoritative reporter in academic writing (some court rules differ).
formatting_requirements: Use official reporter abbreviations per Table T1
Include series notation (2d, 3d, etc.) when applicable
Use U.S. for Supreme Court if available
Omit publisher names (no Lexis/Westlaw in published citations)
For unreported: include docket number, date, and court
For parallel citations: generally cite only official/most-used reporter in law reviews

error_regex_patterns.description: Multiple reporters listed without proper format

sub_rules.rule_title: Parallel Citations and Which Source(s) to Cite
sub_rules.rule_text: When required to provide parallel citations (typically in court documents, not in law reviews), list the citations separated by commas. In law reviews, generally cite only the official or most-used reporter. If citing a public domain citation (for jurisdictions that have adopted such systems), provide that followed by a parallel to a regional reporter if available.
formatting_requirements: Parallel citations separated by commas
Law reviews: cite only official or most-used reporter
Court documents: provide multiple parallel citations
Public domain citations listed first if using public domain system

sub_rules.rule_text: Abbreviate reporter names as per table T1. Use correct series notation (2d, 3d, etc.). Do not include publisher names in citations (no Lexis or Westlaw in a citation to published reporters). For U.S. Supreme Court, cite U.S. if available; otherwise S. Ct., L. Ed., or U.S.L.W. as required.
formatting_requirements: Reporter abbreviations per Table T1
Correct series notation (2d, 3d, etc.)
No publisher names
U.S. preferred for Supreme Court
Alternative Supreme Court reporters: S. Ct., L. Ed., U.S.L.W.

error_regex_patterns.description: Reporter name spelled out instead of abbreviated

sub_rules.rule_text: Some jurisdictions assign official citations that do not depend on a reporter (e.g., '1999 ND 45'). When citing cases in these jurisdictions, use the public domain citation followed by a pinpoint (if any) and the court if not evident, plus the year. If also published in a reporter, some rules require including that as a parallel.
formatting_requirements: Public domain citation format: YYYY Jurisdiction Number
Include pinpoint if needed
Court and year in parentheses if not evident
May include parallel reporter citation

error_regex_patterns.description: Missing court and year when not evident

sub_rules.rule_text: In the parentheses at the end of a citation, include the abbreviation for the court and jurisdiction if not evident from the reporter or context. For state high courts, generally just the state abbreviation and year (e.g., 'N.Y. 1990' for New York Court of Appeals). For intermediate state courts or federal courts, include abbreviations ('Cal. Ct. App.' or '5th Cir.'). Omit the court name if using a state reporter that clearly indicates the court.
formatting_requirements: Court and jurisdiction in final parentheses
State high court: state abbreviation and year
Federal courts: circuit number or court abbreviation
Omit court if evident from reporter
Follow Table T1 for court abbreviations

error_regex_patterns.description: Court name spelled out instead of abbreviated

sub_rules.rule_text: Always include the year of decision in the parentheses after the court/jurisdiction. If the decision date is essential (e.g., multiple decisions by the same court in one year cited together), include the full date. Otherwise, year alone suffices. For U.S. Supreme Court cases, year alone is used. For recent cases not yet published, you might include the full date.
formatting_requirements: Year in parentheses is mandatory
Year alone sufficient for most citations
Full date if essential for clarity
Full date for unpublished/recent cases
U.S. Supreme Court: year only standard

error_regex_patterns.description: Invalid date format (should use month abbreviation or year only)

sub_rules.rule_text: Parenthetical information can be added to case citations to provide additional context about the weight of authority, nature of the ruling, or quoted material.
formatting_requirements: Parentheticals separate from citation parentheses
Weight of authority descriptors: per curiam, en banc, plurality
In chambers opinions noted parenthetically
Interior citations not italicized within parenthetical
Order: weight of authority first, then subsequent history

sub_rules.rule_text: If a decision is per curiam, en banc, or a plurality, indicate that in a parenthetical. For example, (per curiam) or (en banc) or (plurality opinion). Only include if it's not clear from the citation itself or if relevant to the point.
formatting_requirements: Use per curiam, en banc, plurality opinion
Include only if relevant and not clear from context
Not italicized in final parenthetical

sub_rules.rule_text: If citing a single-Justice in-chambers opinion (U.S. Supreme Court), indicate it parenthetically: e.g., '(in chambers)'. This distinguishes such rulings (often on stay applications or similar) from the Court's full opinions.
formatting_requirements: Use (in chambers) for single-Justice opinions
Distinguishes from full Court opinions
Lowercase except for Justice name if included

sub_rules.rule_text: When one case citation is quoted or cited within the parenthetical of another, format the interior citation in normal citation format but do not italicize it (because the parenthetical as a whole is not italicized in law review footnotes, and interior citations remain roman). For example: (quoting Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (1900)).
formatting_requirements: Interior citations in normal format but not italicized
Use quoting or citing verbs
Interior case citations complete but without italics

sub_rules.rule_text: When multiple parentheticals are needed (e.g., one for weight of authority and one for quoted material), the order is: explanatory parenthetical first, then any subsequent history parenthetical. Keep them as separate parentheticals, not one combined.
formatting_requirements: Multiple parentheticals kept separate
Weight of authority first
Subsequent history second
Explanatory information ordered logically

sub_rules.rule_text: Prior and subsequent history of cases should be indicated when relevant to the citation. Abbreviations from Table T8 should be used for common history indicators.
formatting_requirements: Use abbreviations from Table T8
Include only if significant and within two years (for cert. denied)
Subsequent history after main citation
Use sub nom. for changed case names on appeal

sub_rules.rule_title: Explanatory Phrases and Weight of Authority
sub_rules.rule_text: If a case's prior or subsequent history is significant (aff'd, rev'd, cert. denied, etc.), include it in a parenthetical. Use the abbreviations from table T8 ('aff'd', 'rev'd', 'cert. denied'). Only include if the history is not already reflected or if it is within two years for cert. denied (Bluebook rule sets a two-year limit on including cert. denials). Place this parenthetical after the main citation but before any explanatory parenthetical that is about the proposition.
formatting_requirements: Abbreviations from Table T8
cert. denied only within two years
History after main citation
Before explanatory parentheticals
Include full citation for history case if available

error_regex_patterns.description: cert. denied older than two years

sub_rules.rule_text: If the case name changed on appeal (perhaps due to a change in the parties), you may indicate the new name in a parenthetical. For example: (sub nom. New Name v. Original Defendant). Use 'sub nom.' (under the name of) to introduce the new case name.
formatting_requirements: Use sub nom. for name changes
Include full new case name
Place after history citation
Full citation for case under new name

error_regex_patterns.description: sub nom. not used or spelled out
Incomplete case name in sub nom. parenthetical

examples.text: (sub nom. New Name v. Old Defendant, 500 U.S. 123 (2005))

sub_rules.rule_text: Special citation forms are used for pending cases, unreported cases, briefs, and other specialized materials.
formatting_requirements: Pending cases: include docket number, date, court
Unreported cases: database identifier or court website
Briefs: document name, page, case name, docket number
Full dates for pending/unreported cases

sub_rules.rule_text: For cases that are pending (no decision yet) or unreported (no published or official citation), cite to an electronic database (like Westlaw or Lexis) or to the court's filing information. Include docket numbers and court names and full dates for pending/unreported cases. E.g., Brief for Appellant at 15, Smith v. Jones, No. 20-1234 (U.S. filed Jan. 5, 2020).
formatting_requirements: Docket number with No. abbreviation
Full date for pending/unreported
Court name included
Filed date included
Database identifier if electronic

error_regex_patterns.description: Invalid date format (should use month abbreviation)

examples.text: Smith v. Jones, No. 20-1234 (U.S. filed Jan. 5, 2020)

sub_rules.rule_text: When noting a split of authority in the Fifth Circuit (or any circuit), ensure clarity by citing representative cases from both lines of authority. There is no unique format besides providing citations to the cases that demonstrate the split, possibly with a parenthetical explaining it.
formatting_requirements: Cite cases from both sides of split
Use explanatory parenthetical
Standard citation format for each case
May use compare...with structure

error_regex_patterns.description: Multiple authorities on one side without proper grouping

examples.text: Compare Smith v. Jones, 500 F.2d 123 (5th Cir. 2010) (holding X), with Brown v. Green, 600 F.2d 456 (5th Cir. 2015) (holding Y)

sub_rules.rule_text: For briefs and other court filings, include the document name, page (if pinpoint), the case, and the filing info. Example: Brief for Petitioner at 10, Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (No. 18-123). For transcripts, include speaker if relevant and page. Example: Transcript of Oral Argument at 12, Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (No. 18-123).
formatting_requirements: Document name (Brief, Transcript, etc.)
Page or pinpoint citation
Complete case name
Case citation or docket number
Filing information if applicable

error_regex_patterns.description: Brief or transcript without page reference

examples.text: Brief for Petitioner at 10, Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (No. 18-123)
Transcript of Oral Argument at 25, Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (No. 18-123)

sub_rules.rule_text: Cite administrative orders, standing orders, or other court-issued materials by name if available, court, and date. These often are not published; you may refer to the court's website or another source. The Bluebook does not have a specific unique format beyond treating them similar to other court documents or rules, with the title or order number if any.
formatting_requirements: Order name or number
Court identifier
Date of order
Source or website if unpublished
Similar to rule citation format

sub_rules.rule_text: After a full citation of a case, you can use a short form in later citations. Acceptable short forms include the case name (if unique) or a shortened case name, with or without a pinpoint cite, or 'Id.' if the immediately preceding citation is the same case. E.g., 'Roe, 410 U.S. at 116.' Do not use 'supra' or 'hereinafter' for cases.
formatting_requirements: Case name (if unique)
Shortened case name acceptable
Pinpoint may be included
Id. if immediately following same case
No supra or hereinafter

error_regex_patterns.description: Uses supra or hereinafter for case citations

examples.description: Short form for immediately preceding citation
Incorrect - should not use supra for cases
